Text.Value: I must attend to my students. Be on your way.
For his sake, I hope it was a moment of temporary insanity.
Your demonstration was most impressive.
My students earn the most silver swords of any crèche under Vlaakith's command.
Your 'lessons' are reprehensible.
If he has not regained his senses by the time he rejoins my training, his return will be a short and painful one.
But that is for the kith'rak to worry about. My job is to forge the blade, not to decide how it is wielded.

EditorData.NodeContext: Gave away too much, drawing an end to the conversation

Text.Value: I will rectify his behaviour. Swiftly and painfully.

EditorData.NodeContext: ominous - this won't be fun for Varrl

Text.Value: That kainchi poet is no more tolerated in my training room than a ghaik would be tolerated on Vlaakith's throne.

EditorData.NodeContext: as if "poet" is the most disgusting insult of all

Text.Value: I have no interests in whatever delusional beliefs the boy harboured.
Why was the boy refusing to kill?
Chk. Do not dare speak of that pustulent poet in my training room.
Leave.
There are signs that the ghaik presence here goes beyond their usual predation. They are converging on something.
Their potential may not be apparent to your untrained eye, but my methods never fail to extract it.
So we ensure that in our ranks, there are no mistakes.
Ah, our bloodthirsty interlopers.

EditorData.logicalname: Boy Killed By Other Party Member

Text.Value: Ah, our bloodthirsty interloper.
If that boy was a 'taste of Vlaakith's power', I don't have much to worry about.
If that display was a 'taste of Crèche Y'llek's power', I've nothing to worry about.
Vlaakith gha'g shkath zai!
I'm curious. Why make them fight to the death?
Do you know the boy has been reading about Orpheus?
It is up to them to deliver on this potential. They know the punishment if they fail.
Why was the boy refusing to fight?
Chk. Your pathetic intervention spoke for itself - only a lesser crèche would indulge such lenience.
You will learn this first-hand, istik, when we finally come to claim it for our own.
Our warriors must possess strength and skill far superior to any spawned from this putrescent plane.
Every bit of waste I trim away brings us closer to victory against the ghaik infesting these lands.
I've heard reports that ghaik are operating here on an unprecedented scale. They must not be allowed to gain a foothold.
Chk! Not just a coward, but a heretic too.

EditorData.NodeContext: Slightly worried - this makes him look bad.

Text.Value: The boy was a liability. I did what was necessary.
Does your kith'rak know you tolerate your students reading the Orpheus myths?
I am a humble blade tasked with carving out an army.
I wouldn't expect an istik to understand. On this plane, inadequacy is expected.
Did they do things so differently when you were a hatchling?
I will find out if Varrl has truly succumbed to the vile canker of that heretic's words.

EditorData.NodeContext: as if "poet" is the most disgusting insult of all

Text.Value: The slightest mistake, the smallest hesitation, and you die. The warrior next to you dies. A hundred more behind them.
The hatchlings live to serve Vlaakith, or they do not live at all.
Precisely. The foe he spares may be the one to rise up and tear out your gullet.
I do what is necessary, and no worse than our enemies would do.
Cruelty carves cunning. It has made me what I am.
Happy to help. The students didn't seem to be learning much from you.
If I am not convinced of his loyalty to our glorious queen, then I will cure him.

EditorData.NodeContext: ominous - this won't be fun for Varrl

Text.Value: If the boy was too stupid to realise this, his death is a mercy for the warrior next to him.
Did you know the boy was a believer in Orpheus?
I doubt it matters. Based on what I just saw, your students are a lost cause.
I doubt it will matter. Your hatchlings are not fit to serve Vlaakith.
The illithids infecting this region are not to be reasoned with. They are to be exterminated.
What is it? These insufferable interruptions are distracting from my lessons.
There are whispers of ghaik gathering in unusual numbers nearby. They are not here to negotiate.
We will eradicate them, ra'stil, and when we do, you will be grateful our warriors are so carefully chosen.

EditorData.NodeContext: smug, thinks his are the best warriors

Text.Value: Our wars are waged against ghaik, not bandits and petty thieves.

EditorData.NodeContext: Sneering, implying this is all the player is fit for

Text.Value: Did you enjoy our little demonstration? A mere taste of the power Vlaakith commands.
Did you enjoy our little demonstration? A mere taste of the power Crèche Y'llek commands.
The name pollutes the very air expelled in its uttering.
Vlaakith would delight in your ruthlessness here, I'm sure.
There should be plenty of heads for my students to take when their final test begins.
Are your 'demonstrations' usually so fatal?
I hear they have been gathering nearby in greater numbers than usual.
Your 'demonstration' was reprehensible.
A ridiculous notion. No student of mine would be permitted to indulge such heresies.

Synopsis: Following the conclusion of the Githboy scene, the player has a follow up interaction with the teacher where they comment on his methods, and the scene's outcome.
